info.name: IBPublic_Generic.PostmanCollection - Cleansed
info.description:
## IB Public API Collection

Welcome to the IB Public API Collection.

This collection aims to provide a convenient way to interact with IB public APIs in a controlled environment and without writing any code. The collection also aims to introduce you to common use-cases that may be solved programmatically using our APIs.

Whether you are a developer, project manager, or busines owner, we trust IB public APIs will empower you to build foscused experiences and solutions for your customers.

item.name: Authentication

exec: const assertion = makeJws(forge, jwtPrivateKey, header, claims);

urlencoded.value: accounts.read accounts.write bank-instructions.read bank-instructions.write clients.read clients.write echo.read echo.write fee-templates.read fee-templates.write instructions.read instructions.write statements.read transfers.read transfers.write sso-sessions.write sso-browser-sessions.write enumerations.read

item.description:
IB Public APIs use the [OAuth 2.0 protocol](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749) for authentication and authorization.

Given the nature of our business, **IB has chosen to only support private_key_jwt client authentication** as described in [RFC 7521](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7521.html) and [RFC 7523](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc7523.html).This means that **a client authenticates against the authorization server by presenting a signed JWT token** called a _client_assertion_ which the authorization server validates against the public key(s) provided by the client during registration. This scheme is considered safer than the standard client id/client secret authentication scheme used in early OAuth 2.0 integrations given that it prevents the client from having to pass the client secret in back-end requests.

Please note this collection makes heavy use of Postman [environments](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/managing-environments/), [pre-request scripts](https://learning.postman.com/docs/writing-scripts/pre-request-scripts/) and [test scripts](https://learning.postman.com/docs/writing-scripts/test-scripts/) to provide you with a cohesive experience. Please consult our API guide for full technical information on API authentication.

## Requesting access tokens

Most APIs documented in this collection are considered [protected resources](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6749#section-7). As such, you are required to obtain an access token before being granted access to the API. These tokens contain a **scope** parameter which describes what you are allowed to do with a given access token. Examples include _accounts.close_, _clients.read_, _transfers.write_.

The requests below show how to request access tokens against the OAuth 2.0 authorization server.

item.description:
**Allowed scopes**: echo.read echo.write

The **echo** resource is a special resource meant to provide an easy way to test integrations. The echo resource simplies _echoes_ back the incoming request after the request is considered valid by the gateway.
